awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Composable Platform as a Service Instrument for Deep Learning & Visualization (COMPaaS DLV)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is about acquiring a much-in-demand Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)-based instrument, to develop a Service Instrument for Deep Learning and Visualization called "COMPaaS DLV: COMposable Platform".  The project aims to complement available campus computing resources via the campus's research network. It will be able to access local and remote computing and storage facilities funded, including XSEDE, Blue Waters, Deep Learning Instrument and Chameleon. This critical instrumentation will provide a platform to pursue fundamental science and engineering research training in deep learning (data mining and data analytics, computer vision, natural language processing, artificial intelligence), visualization (simulation, rendering, visual analytics, video steaming, image processing), and a combination of deep learning and visualization (e.g., when data is so large that it cannot be easily visualized, then deep learning is used to extract features of interest to be visualized). The instrumentation also enables investigation and contribution to societal issues in disciplines such as anthropology, biology, cybersecurity, data-literacy, fraud detection, healthcare, manufacturing, urban sustainability, and cyber-physical systems (e.g., autonomous cars). 

Its design utilizes state-of-the-art computer architecture, known as composable architecture, in which the computer's components (traditional processor, GPU, storage, and networking) form a fluid pool of resources, such that different applications with different workflows can be run simultaneously, with each configuring the resources it requires almost instantaneously, at any time. Given composable infrastructure scalability and agility, it is more beneficial than traditional clouds and clusters that are rigid, overprovisioned, and expensive.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Illinois Chicago (UIC) acquired a much-in-demand instrument named COMPaaS DLV: COMposable Platform as a Service Instrument for Deep Learning & Visualization. COMPaaS is a mid-scale computer system that, via the campus's research network, can access local computing resources as well as federally-funded computing and storage facilities across the nation.

While the aforementioned campus and community resources are beneficial, they are often limiting - particularly for deep learning and visualization - as they have few, if any, available Graphics Processing Units (GPUs). GPUs more efficiently perform mathematical operations that can be massively parallelized, speeding up codes used in deep learning / machine learning / artificial intelligence, visualization and image processing, moreso than general-purpose microprocessors, or CPUs (central processing units). In today's Big Data era, data scientists require GPU-based computational instruments to more quickly analyze large-scale datasets using complex codes and quicken the rate of scientific progress. COMPaaS is a GPU-based computer system.

Its design utilizes 4th-generation, state-of-the-art computer architecture, known as composable infrastructure, in which the computer's components - CPU, GPU, storage, memory and networking - form a fluid pool of resources over a high-speed fabric, such that different applications with different workflows can run simultaneously, with each configuring the resources it requires almost instantaneously, at any time. COMPaaS is a highly flexible, scalable, high-throughput system for Big Data.

Given our early adoption of this new computer architecture, we discovered that the vendor's tools to configure infrastructure resources and manage application workflows were time consuming to use and difficult to deploy to end users - data science, computer science and computer engineering researchers with diverse workflows - who lack knowledge of the underlying hardware. We developed solutions to enable our users to dynamically manipulate composable machine resources and to quickly move jobs across different hardware configurations, while also providing programmability and reproducibility and maintaining security and persistence. To ensure adoption, we integrated our tools with users' scientific workflows. Modern workflows are moving to containers and cloud frameworks (using Kubernetes) and to programming notebooks (primarily Jupyter), both for ease of use and for ensuring reproducible experiments.

We now have over 40 UIC College of Engineering faculty, postdocs and students using COMPaaS, and we get more requests regularly. The system is open to additional science and engineering faculty and students as availability and demand permit.

Given composable infrastructure's scalability and agility, it is more beneficial than traditional clouds and clusters that are rigid, overprovisioned and expensive. Also, commercial public clouds, like Amazon Web Services (AWS), offer some functionality, but are primarily designed as a single-node model, not a collection of resources for research, and the networking is not practical for data-intensive applications, with slow transfer rates to move data in and out at high cost.

Intellectual merit. COMPaaS is critical instrumentation that provides UIC faculty and students with a platform on which to pursue fundamental science and engineering research and research training in deep learning, visualization, image processing, and a combination of deep learning and visualization. It enables UIC faculty to investigate and contribute to solutions to societal issues, in disciplines such as anthropology, biology, cybersecurity, data literacy, fraud detection, healthcare, manufacturing, urban sustainability, and cyber-physical systems (e.g., autonomous cars).

Broader impacts. COMPaaS was acquired by researchers at the UIC Electronic Visualization Laboratory (EVL), a Computer Science research laboratory that specializes in visualization but has a long-standing reputation as a high-performance computing (HPC) technology enabler for research and research training. The COMPaaS instrument, along with the tools EVL developed and integrated with modern scientific workflows to manage infrastructure and applications, enables UIC faculty, students and postdocs to easily execute deep learning and visualization codes, apply sophisticated models to large-scale problems, gain greater insights, accelerate discovery, and open new avenues of research.

The instrument enables UIC to recruit new faculty who are attracted to institutions that can support their computational needs, and to recruit new students and produce a better trained workforce - which in turn attracts industrial partnerships. UIC is a Minority Serving Institution, Hispanic Serving Institution, and Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-Serving Institution, and the research enabled by this instrument will help recruit and retain underrepresented students pursuing STEM degrees.
